facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1838 of 1967 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 1838 of 1967. Appeal by special leave from the Judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from Judgment and Order dated 23rd May 1967 of Calcutta High Court in Civil Rule No. 1119 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 23rd May, 1967 of the Calcutta High Court in Civil Rule No. 11 19 of 1962.

facts.text: Gobinda Prasad Pandit, founder of Searsole Raj Estate, died in 1861 leaving a will.

anchor.surface_text: Gobinda Prasad Pandit, the founder of the Searsole Raj Estate died in the year 1861 leaving a will.

facts.text: After Gobinda Prasad Pandit's death, suit held that charge created on entire estate for maintenance, seva puja of family deity and specified charitable purposes.

anchor.surface_text: After his death in a suit between his widow and certain other claimants regarding the title to the estate it was held that a charge had been created upon the entire estate for the maintenance and seva puja of the family deity and for the performance of certain specified charitable purposes.

facts.text: In 1928, appellant, his brother and father executed arpannamah in favour of family deity reiterating the charge.

anchor.surface_text: In 1928 the appellant, his brother and their father who succeeded to the estate executed an arpannamah in favour of the family deity reiterating the charge created by Gobinda Prasad Pandit.

facts.text: On October 12, 1953, appellant executed document setting apart half share in part of estate exclusively for charged purposes, rest free, appointed himself trustee.

anchor.surface_text: On October 12, 1953 the appellant executed a document whereby a half share in a part of the estate was set apart exclusively for the purpose for which the charge had been created earlier, and the rest of the property was to be treated as absolutely free and absolved from the claims in respect of the religious and charitable purposes. The appellant appointed himself as the trustee.

facts.text: West Bengal Estates Acquisition Act, 1953 came into force on 12-2-1954.

anchor.surface_text: The West Bengal Estates Acquisition Act, 1953 came into force on 12-2-1954.

facts.text: Estate vested in State on 14-4-1955.

anchor.surface_text: Under that Act, ... the estate vested in the State on 14-4-1955.

facts.text: Act amended introducing section 5A with retrospective effect from 5-5-1953.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently the Act was amended by introducing section 5A therein with retrospective effect from 5-5-1953, the date prior to that on which the bill, which later became the West Bengal Estates Acquisition Act, was published in the Gazette.

facts.text: Settlement Officer held document executed on October 12, 1953 not bona fide after enquiry.

anchor.surface_text: After an enquiry the Settlement Officer held that the document executed by the appellant on October 12, 1953 was number bona fide.

facts.text: Appeal against Settlement Officer's decision to Special Judge failed.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal against this decision to the Special Judge failed and so also a petition filed before the High Court under Art. 227 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Petition to High Court under Art. 227 failed.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal against this decision to the Special Judge failed and so also a petition filed before the High Court under Art. 227 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Appeal filed pursuant to special leave granted by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal has been filed in pursuance of the special leave granted by this Court.

facts.text: Appellant is an intermediary.

anchor.surface_text: It may be stated even at this stage that the appellant is an intermediary.

facts.text: Settlement Officer found total expenditure on seva and charitable purposes Rs. 30,000/-, appellant's share Rs.15,000/- .

anchor.surface_text: It is found from that order itself that the total expenditure on the seva and charitable purposes was Rs. 30,000/- and the appellants share therein would be Rs.15,000/-.

facts.text: Income of land absolutely transferred under deed of October 12, 1953 is Rs. 23,000/- .

anchor.surface_text: It is also found that the income of the land absolutely transferred under the deed of October 12, 1953 is Rs. 23,000/- .

facts.text: Without document, appellant would have whole estate with charge of Rs. 15,000/- .

anchor.surface_text: But for the execution of the document the appellant would have been in possession of the whole of the estate with only a charge amounting to Rs. 15,000/- .

facts.text: Court holds document is a transfer by gift to deity.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the High Court as well as the authorities below were right in this companyclusion. The definition of the term transfer does number attract all the definitions. ... If the substance of the transaction by which properties are endowed in favour of a deity is looked into we do number see why it cannot be called a gift.

facts.text: Settlement Officer did not properly consider if transfer made to increase land retained or compensation.

anchor.surface_text: the Settlement Officer did number apply his mind to the provisions of the Act which lay down what transfers would be held to be number bona fide. He, did number companysider whether the transfer was made principally or partially with the object of increasing the amount of land which the transferor may retain or increasing the amount of companypensation payable to him.

facts.text: Special Judge held appellant transferred interest in remaining portion to son and wife.

anchor.surface_text: the fact that the appellant transferred his interest in the remaining portion of the estate to his son and wife clearly established want of bona fides

facts.text: Appeal allowed, High Court to dispose afresh.

anchor.surface_text: In the result this appeal is allowed. The High Court will dispose of the matter a fresh in accordance with law. There will be. numberorder, as to companyts.

facts.text: Earlier 1928 document and prior decree do not bring lands under section 6(1)(i).

anchor.surface_text: The earlier document of 1928 as well as the prior decree would number bring the lands under this section at all, as was held by this Court in Fazlul Rabbi Pradhan v. State of West Bengal 1965 3 SCR 307.

facts.text: Appellant inherited moiety share subject to charge.

anchor.surface_text: how the appellant who inherited the moiety share of the estate subject to the charge was legally companypetent

facts.text: Land yielding larger income transferred absolutely to deity as result of document.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of the document land yielding a larger income was transferred absolutely to the deity.
The appeal against this decision to the Special Judge failed and so also a petition filed before the High Court under Art. 227 of the Constitution.
Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and Order dated the 23rd May, 1967 of the Calcutta High Court in Civil Rule No. 11 19 of 1962.
This appeal has been filed in pursuance of the special leave granted by this Court.

concepts.interpretation: Introduces enquiry into transfers from 5-5-1953 to vesting; retrospective effect; if not bona fide, transfer cancelled.

concepts.unlisted_description: Provision for enquiry and cancellation of non-bona fide transfers by intermediaries post specified date.

anchor.surface_text: Under S. 4 1  of the Act a numberification may be issued by the State Government that all estates and the rights of every intermediary in each such estate shall vest in the State free from all encumbrances.

concepts.unlisted_description: Notification for vesting of estates free from encumbrances.

anchor.surface_text: Under S. 5 1  upon the publication of such a numberification the estates and the rights of intermediaries in the estates shall vest in the State free from all encumbrances.

holdings.text: The document executed on October 12, 1953 constitutes a transfer by gift within the meaning of section 5A of the West Bengal Estates Acquisition Act as dedication/endowment of property to a deity is in substance a gift and the definition of transfer is not limited to those in the Transfer of Property Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms lower courts; statutory definition of transfer includes gift and substance of endowment to deity is gift; follows Calcutta High Court precedent in Champa Bibi.

holdings.text: The Settlement Officer, Special Judge and High Court failed to properly determine whether the transfer was not bona fide under section 5A(7) as they did not consider or reason whether it was made principally or partially to increase retainable land or compensation payable.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower authorities merely recited section words without analyzing facts like income Rs.23,000 vs charge Rs.15,000 or transfers to family; no reasons given on whether it increased retention/compensation.

holdings.text: The facts of the case do not raise any question under section 6(1)(i) of the West Bengal Estates Acquisition Act.

anchor.surface_text: We do number companysider that the facts of this case raise any question under section 6 1   i  at all. That can arise only with regard to the situation as it existed before the execution of the impugned document and under the unamended Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.6(1)(i) applies to pre-document situation under unamended Act only.

holdings.text: The 1928 arpannamah and prior decree do not bring the lands under section 6(1)(i).

anchor.surface_text: The earlier document of 1928 as well as the prior decree would number bring the lands under this section at all, as was held by this Court in Fazlul Rabbi Pradhan v. State of West Bengal 1965 3 SCR 307.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Directly follows Supreme Court precedent in Fazlul Rabbi Pradhan.
